headlines: ‘Under new management’
contents:
When I was young and silly, I walked the streets in Manila on hot summer days to hunt for a full-time job. After graduating from a university high school in the country’s typhoon belt, I wanted to pursue college education in the university belt in Manila. But I first needed a job to finance my college education. Before I enrolled in college, I literally walked along Taft, Escolta, Dasmariñas, Tetuan, Avenida Rizal and Azcarraga to find a decent albeit menial job. There was no internet, Google or company websites then to make job hunting easy. Every day, I would meet ever changing faces coming my way, as I looked at street signs to my right and left. I would read familiar messages — NO Vacancy, Mail, Wanted Houseboy: Apply Inside, Beware of Dog (or its variation which warns “Forget the Dog, Beware the Owner”), Post No Bill, Do Not Enter, Under Renovation, or Under New Management. I knew what the other signs meant, but I was curious what “new management” would look like. I would often wonder, “Is the new management grumpier and greedier or kinder and more generous than the old one?” Game changer
My first encounter with a Manager reminded me how small I was in the overall scheme of things, especially in the context of my position as messenger (with a lower case “m”). I didn’t know if that was how Managers at that time were taught to behave, but I noticed that most managers would almost always maintain a certain distance between them and their subordinates. Many were autocratic, spoke in measured manner and tone, and could not care less how demeaning they would often treat other people. Fortunately, in 1960, Douglas McGregor wrote a book that helped me change my outlook about management. He was a management professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology during the 1950s and 1960s, and his book was called, “The Human Side of Enterprise.” McGregor proposed that there are two alternative ways by which managers perceive and address employee motivation. According to McGregor, Theory X management assumes that people dislike work and will avoid it if they could; that people are not ambitious and would rather be directed; and that people are gullible, resist change, and should be coerced and controlled if you expect them to help achieve organizational goals. Conversely, Theory Y management assumes that people consider work as natural as play and rest, are responsible and, given the right conditions, will seek responsibility. People can be committed to achieve quality and productivity goals if the right rewards are in place. It was McGregor who first pointed out that a “command-and-control” environment is not effective. In early corporate America, “command-and-control” was the norm — thanks to retired Generals who were rewarded with corporate positions after World War 2. McGregor thought that the essence of “command-and-control” relies on lower needs for motivation, which are mostly satisfied already among the majority of employees. This theory was a corollary to Abraham Maslow’s “Hierarchy of Needs Theory.” When employees lose their motivation, they will tend to dislike their work, avoid responsibility, resist change, etc. That creates a self-fulfilling prophecy. Change drivers
Among enlightened managers, McGregor’s simple concept was a game changer. Over the years, when the “profession” of management developed to its fullness in the 1980s and 1990s, a bunch of enlightened Theory Y managers created a critical mass that swayed the practice of management towards how we experience it today. Also, there are significant change drivers that forced the practice of management to change. First is technology. The management practice championed by Frederick Winslow Taylor during the First Industrial Revolution was based on the technology in the days of Henry Ford, who leveraged the production line for utmost efficiency. Today and in the future, the Internet of Things will have a tremendous impact on the way managers will relate with their subordinates. In fact, even the face of management is now changing. In some cases, and where robotics and artificial intelligence have fully set into workplace processes, subordinates are already taking orders from C-3PO (the speaking, walking humanoid robot in “Star Wars”). Lest human managers and supervisors become irrelevant, they must be tech savvy now and in the future. To stay relevant, managers must have empathy and compassion — something that robot supervisors still don’t have. Second is information. As information almost doubles every year, it has become a most important global resource. Managers must have information at their fingertips in order to manage effectively. Enough said! The third is the changing demographics. Today, the majority of the inhabitants of the workplace are between their 20s and 30s. The elderly managers must adjust their management style to make these workplace inhabitants tick. Enough said, too! Managing in the next normal
Management and leadership will continue to change, as the business of doing business changes. In the next normal, managers must be able to adapt to the changing environment or C-3PO will take their jobs. Here are some of the requisites for managing in the next normal: – Caring. The Covid-19 pandemic provided lessons that managers did not learn in Management 101. Henceforth, managers are expected to be deeply concerned about employees’ safety, health and overall well-being. People expect to work in a safe environment that offers them not just ample pay and benefits, but a sense of belonging, social contact and a semblance of normalcy. – Character and integrity. Employees prefer to work with managers who share the same values with them. Managers must live and demonstrate in no uncertain terms the Company’s mission and values, in a way that people can feel and empathize with. While being transparent with organizational and environmental realities, managers must exude optimism and hope, inspire, and motivate their people. – Competence. Skills are the new currency of the future. Emerging managerial roles require an elaborate mix of hard and soft skills. While intelligence quotient (IQ) remains constant, emotional quotient (EQ) can be developed and improved over time. EQ and adversity quotient (AQ) are among the soft skills that will help managers succeed when the going gets tougher. Managers must indulge in intentional lifelong learning in order to stay sharp, smart, and relevant. – Crisis-proofing. Businesses, brands and people that survive during crises are generally purpose-driven. Revisit your purpose; find a niche that is aligned with your purpose. Managers must develop resilient strategies for business continuity and sustainability. In like manner, they should develop even more creative strategies for career continuity and sustainability. Amid the growing uncertainty, managers must learn to adapt to the neck-breaking speed at which changes in the global environment occur. In a recent online management and leadership forum, I told managers to “[c]hallenge your current assumptions about management and leadership in the next normal. When the smoke clears, we could be seeing a different landscape in the workplace that will require a different set of managerial and leadership skills. Upskill and reskill to be relevant.” Obviously, there are new and emerging dimensions in management that were different from what Taylor, Ford, McGregor and Maslow saw during their time. This is the time for “new management” in uncertain times. Klaus Schwab, founder and executive chairman of the World Economic Forum, said, “There are four ingredients in true leadership: brains, soul, heart and good nerves.” The whole world is still in deep trouble. Perhaps, it should be “Under New Management.” Ernie Cecilia is the chairman of the Human Capital Committee of the American Chamber of Commerce of the Philippines (AMCHAM); Co-Chairman of the Employers Confederation of the Philippines’ (ECOP’s) TWG on Labor Policy and Social Issues; and past president of the People Management Association of the Philippines (PMAP). He can be reached at erniececilia@gmail.com

headlines: PH tallies 1,557 new Covid cases
contents: THE Philippines logged 1,557 new cases of the coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) on Wednesday, according to the Department of Health (DoH), raising the total number of infections to 566,420. More than 95 percent of the 30,970 active cases are mild, moderate or asymptomatic while the rest remain severe or critical. There are 523,321 recoveries, including 392 that were added on Wednesday. The death toll is up to 12,129 with 22 new fatalities. The country has a 7.5 percent positivity rate, with 1,727 out of 23,170 samples yielding positive results.

headlines: Palace distances self from Tulfo claim on Sinopharm vaccines
contents: MALACANANG has distanced itself from the claim of special envoy to China Ramon “Mon” Tulfo Jr. that President Rodrigo Duterte sought to obtain samples of China-made Sinopharm vaccines even as it has yet to secure an emergency use authorization (EUA) from the Food and Drug Administration (FDA). “I don’t understand the big deal about the Mon Tulfo write up. That’s an account of Mon Tulfo and if you want verification please contact Mon Tulfo because I cannot answer on his behalf,” Roque told reporters in a press conference on Wednesday. Roque said he was not belying the claim of Tulfo but said the President did not deal directly with a Sinopharm representative. “He did not deal directly with Sinopharm as in fact we still cannot import Sinopharm [on a large scale basis] beyond the compassionate use license issued by FDA,” said Roque. Tulfo wrote in his column published in The Manila Times last February 20 that Duterte spoke with a Sinopharm local representative and asked for vaccines for himself and his family.

headlines: Palace invites Robredo to join volunteer public officials for Sinovac inoculation
contents: MALACANANG on Wednesday invited Vice President Maria Leonor “Leni” Robredo to join public officials who volunteered to be among the first to be inoculated with the coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) vaccine manufactured by Sinovac Biotech. “Kung papayagan tayo ng National Task Force [against Covid-19] at [the] Department of Health ay kasama tayo sa mauunang magpabakuna para magbigay kumpyansa sa ating mga kababayan para mawala ang kanilang agam-agam (If the National Task Force [against Covid-19] and the Department of Health will permit, we will be joining the first individuals who will receive the vaccine to boost public confidence and to allay vaccine fears).” “Kung gusto po ni Vice President, she’s welcome to join also (If the Vice President wants to volunteer, she’s welcome to join also).” Roque said he was among those who volunteered. Vaccine czar Carlito Galvez Jr., Health Secretary Francisco Duque 3rd, Defense Secretary Delfin Lorenzana are also ready to be inoculated with Sinovac, Roque said.

headlines: MMDA buys AstraZeneca vaccines for 8,000 employees
contents: THE Metropolitan Manila Development Authority (MMDA) has placed an order of AstraZeneca vaccines for the coronavirus disease 2019 for its 8,000 employees, the agency chief said on Wednesday. MMDA Chairman Benhur Abalos said the order from the British-Swedish multinational corporation was made during the time of the late chairman Danilo Lim. “Kami sa (We in the) MMDA got vaccines under late Chairman Danny Lim,” Abalos said in a Kapihan sa Manila Bay media forum. “It’s good for 8,000 employees.” Abalos told a Kapihan sa Manila Bay media forum on Wednesday that the MMDA has advanced 20 percent of the payment for the vaccines but did not elaborate, citing the agreed non disclosure agreement between the government agency and the pharmaceutical firm. However, Abalos also noted that only around 50 percent of MMDA employees were willing to be inoculated. The MMDA earmarked P20 million for vaccines last year at the height of the pandemic.

headlines: 55 Pasay villages under ‘localized community quarantine’
contents: FIFTY-FIVE villages in Pasay City were placed under “localized community quarantine” as the city was flagged for increased number of coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) cases. BUSINESS AS USUAL Shoppers once again crowd stalls in Baclaran, PasayCity, some forgetting to observe minimum health protocols. PHOTO BY J. GERARD SEGUIA

headlines: Trillanes to Duterte: ‘Focus on vaccine rollout, will have you jailed in 2022’
contents: FORMER senator Antonio Trillanes 4th on Wednesday warned that he will send President Rodrigo Duterte “to jail” in 2022. He made the threat in response to Duterte’s tirade against him, describing him as a “devil”. The President also warned Filipinos not to vote for Trillanes in the 2022 national elections. Trillanes has “advised” Duterte to focus on the rollout of the coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) vaccine instead of paying attention to him. “Kitang kita ang takot sa mga pananalita ni Duterte (Duterte’s fear was shown in the way he talks),” Trillanes said in a text message “Relax lang sya (He should just relax). Tutukan lang n’ya ang (He must focus on the) vaccine rollout,” he continued. Trillanes added, “Next year pa naman namin sya ipapakulong (We’ll send him to jail next year). On Jan. 14, 2020, Trillanes said the decision of lawyer Jude Sabio to withdraw his communication before the International Criminal Court (ICC) has no effect on the case against humanity that he filed against Duterte. He said the judicial process in the ICC is different from the justice system in the Philippines. “The plan of Sabio to withdraw the ICC case has no effect because that is not the process of ICC,” Trillanes previously said. “The ones who gave the testimony in the complaint filed by Sabio were the witnesses Arturo Lascañas and Edgar Matobato),” he said. Trillanes added, “Sabio was merely their lawyer who facilitated writing their testimonies. Even assuming that Sabio’s withdrawal is accepted, there were many other people who filed [a case] against Duterte before the ICC),” he said. Trillanes noted that he and former partylist representative Gary Alejano also filed a complaint against Duterte before the ICC in June 2017. This was used as basis for the conduct in February 2018 of the preliminary examination on the case against Duterte, Trillanes said. “The attempt to reach out to Sabio by Duterte forces was a clear indication that Duterte has become nervous about the ICC case,” Trillanes said.

headlines: Mongolia receives COVID-19 vaccine donation from China
contents: ULAN BATOR, Feb. 22 (Xinhua) — Mongolia on Monday night received 300,000 doses of Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine donated by China. Staff members prepare to unload COVID-19 vaccines donated by China at the Chinggis Khaan International Airport in Ulan Bator, Mongolia, Feb. 23, 2021. Mongolia on Monday night received 300,000 doses of Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine donated by China. (Xinhua/Asigang) The vaccine donation was welcomed at the Chinggis Khaan International Airport in Mongolia’s capital city of Ulan Bator by Mongolian Deputy Prime Minister Sainbuyan Amarsaikhan and Chinese Ambassador to Mongolia Chai Wenrui. “On behalf of the Mongolian government and people, I would like to express my deep gratitude to China, our friendly neighbor and comprehensive strategic partner, for extending its helping hand during this difficult time,” said Amarsaikhan. “There is a Mongolian saying that goes, ‘Close neighbors have one life, far away neighbors have one mind.’ Since the start of the COVID-19 outbreak, Mongolia and China have provided each other with material and emotional support, which is a real example of how neighboring countries are overcoming difficulties together,” he said. For his part, Chai said, “The current global vaccine supply and demand are very tight. China has overcome difficulties when its own vaccine supply is not sufficient, and has not hesitated to give 300,000 doses of vaccine to Mongolia free of charge, which shows that China attaches great importance to China-Mongolia relations and the friendship between the two peoples.” The Chinese ambassador expressed confidence that these vaccines will contribute to the protection of people’s lives and the fight against the pandemic in Mongolia. Mongolia is planning to vaccinate at least 60 percent of its 3.3 million people, or all adults in the country, against the coronavirus, with 20 percent of them to be vaccinated under COVAX, a global initiative to ensure quick and equal access to vaccines against the virus, according to the country’s health ministry. The Asian country is expected to launch a nationwide COVID-19 vaccination campaign on Tuesday. As of Monday, the country recorded 2,693 COVID-19 cases, with six deaths.

headlines: Not to be sniffed at: Agony of post-Covid-19 loss of smell
contents: NICE, France: The doctor slid a miniature camera into the patient’s right nostril, making her whole nose glow red with its bright miniature light. “Tickles a bit, eh?” he asked as he rummaged around her nasal passages, the discomfort causing tears to well in her eyes and roll down her cheeks. The patient, Gabriella Forgione, wasn’t complaining. The 25-year-old pharmacy worker was happy to be prodded and poked at the hospital in Nice, in southern France, to advance her increasingly pressing quest to recover her sense of smell. Along with her sense of taste, it suddenly vanished when she fell ill with Covid-19 in November, and neither has returned. Being deprived of the pleasures of food and the scents of things that she loves are proving tough on her body and mind. Shorn of odors both good and bad, Forgione is losing weight and self-confidence. “Sometimes I ask myself, ‘Do I stink?'” she confessed. “Normally, I wear perfume and like for things to smell nice. Not being able to smell bothers me greatly.” A year into the coronavirus pandemic, doctors and researchers are still striving to better understand and treat the accompanying epidemic of Covid-19-related anosmia — loss of smell — draining much of the joy of life from an increasing number of sensorially frustrated longer-term sufferers like Forgione. Gabriella Forgione, a 25-year-old patient, holds still as a doctor slides a miniature camera up her nose during tests in a hospital in Nice, France on Monday, Feb. 8, 2021, to help determine why she has been unable to smell or taste since she contracted Covid-19 in November 2020. AP PHOTO Even specialist doctors say there is much about the condition they still don’t know and they are learning as they go along in their diagnoses and treatments. Impairment and alteration of smell have become so common with Covid-19 that some researchers suggest that simple odor tests could be used to track coronavirus infections in countries with few laboratories. For most people, the olfactory problems are temporary, often improving on their own in weeks. But a small minority are complaining of persistent dysfunction long after other Covid-19 symptoms have disappeared. Some have reported continued total or partial loss of smell six months after infection. The longest, some doctors say, are now approaching a full year. Researchers working on the vexing disability say they are optimistic that most will eventually recover but fear some will not. Some doctors are concerned that growing numbers of smell-deprived patients, many of them young, could be more prone to depression and other difficulties and weigh on strained health systems. “They are losing color in their lives,” said Dr. Thomas Hummel, who heads the smell and taste outpatients clinic at University Hospital in Dresden, Germany. “These people will survive and they’ll be successful in their lives, in their professions,” Hummel added. “But their lives will be much poorer.” At the Face and Neck University Institute in Nice, Dr. Clair Vandersteen wafted tube after tube of odors under Forgione’s nose after he had rooted around in her nostrils with his camera. “Do you perceive any smell? Nothing? Zero? OK,” he asked, as she repeatedly and apologetically responded with negatives. Only the last tube provoked an unequivocal reaction. “Urgh! Oh, that stinks,” Forgione yelped. “Fish!” Test complete, Vandersteen delivered his diagnosis. “You need an enormous amount of an odor to be able to smell something,” he told her. “You haven’t completely lost your sense of smell but nor is it good.” The hand of Dr. Clair Vandersteen wafts a tube of odors under the nose of a blindfolded patient, Gabriella Forgione, during tests in a hospital in Nice, southern France, Monday, Feb. 8, 2021. AP PHOTO He sent her away with homework: six months of olfactory rehab. Twice daily, choose two or three scented things, like a sprig of lavender or jars of fragrances, and smell them for two to three minutes, he ordered. “If you smell something, great. If not, no problem. Try again, concentrating hard on picturing the lavender, a beautiful purple bloom,” he said. “You have to persevere.” Losing the sense of smell can be more than a mere inconvenience. Smoke from a spreading fire, a gas leak, or the stink of rotten food can all pass dangerously unnoticed. Fumes from a used diaper, dog’s dirt on a shoe or sweaty armpits can be embarrassingly ignored. And as poets have long known, scents and emotions are often like lovers entwined. Evan Cesa used to relish meal times. Now they’re a chore. A fish dinner in September that suddenly seemed flavorless first flagged to the 18-year-old sports student that COVID-19 had attacked his senses. Foodstuffs became mere textures, with only residual hints of sweet and saltiness. Five months later, breakfasting on chocolate cookies before classes, Cesa still chewed without joy, as though swallowing cardboard. “Eating no longer has any purpose for me,” he said. “It is just a waste of time.” Cesa is among the anosmia sufferers being studied by researchers in Nice who, before the pandemic, had been using scents in the diagnosis of Alzheimer’s disease. They also used comforting fragrances to treat post-traumatic stress among children after a truck terror attack in Nice in 2016, when a driver plowed through holiday crowds, killing 86 people. Dr. Clair Vandersteen (right) wafts a tube of odors under the nose of a patient, Gabriella Forgione. AP PHOTO The researchers are now turning their expertise to Covid-19, teaming up with perfumers from the nearby fragrance-producing town of Grasse. Perfumer Aude Galouye worked on the fragrant waxes that were wafted under Cesa’s nose to measure his olfactory impairment, with scents at varying concentrations. “The sense of smell is a sense that is fundamentally forgotten,” Galouye said. “We don’t realize the effect it has on our lives except, obviously, when we no longer have it.” The examinations on Cesa and other patients also include language and attention tests. The Nice researchers are exploring whether olfactory complaints are linked to Covid-related cognitive difficulties, including problems with concentrating. Cesa stumbled by picking the word “ship” when “kayak” was the obvious choice on one test. “That is completely unexpected,” said Magali Payne, a speech therapist on the team. “This young man shouldn’t be experiencing linguistic problems.” “We have to keep digging,” she said. “We are finding things out as we see patients.” Cesa longs to have his senses restored, to celebrate the taste of pasta in carbonara sauce, his favorite dish, and a run through the fragrant wonders of the great outdoors. “One might think that it is not important to be able to smell nature, trees, forests,” he said. “But when you lose the sense of smell, you realize how truly lucky we are to be able to smell these things.”

headlines: Govt eyes further reopening of industries under GCQ–Nograles
contents: THE Duterte economic team will look for ways to further reopen more industries in areas under general community quarantine (GCQ) in a bid to curb the rising unemployment and hunger rate amid the coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) pandemic. Cabinet Secretary Karlo Nograles said this in a press conference on Tuesday after President Rodrigo Duterte rejected the proposal of the Inter-Agency Task Force for the Management of Emerging Infectious Diseases (IATF-EID) to place the entire country under the most lenient modified general community quarantine (MGCQ). Nograles also said there was a possibility that the government will further relax restrictions imposed in areas under GCQ. “There are ways and means for us to safely reopen the economy some more within the framework of GCQ,” he added. Nograles said the Cabinet supports the decision of the President to defer the shift to MGCQ until after the start of the nationwide vaccination. “There is wisdom in the President’s decision,” he said.

headlines: Mayors ‘defer’ to Duterte over GCQ status in Metro Manila
contents: MAYORS will “defer” to President Rodrigo Duterte’s decision to keep the general community quarantine (GCQ) in Metro Manila unless there is a vaccine, the Metropolitan Manila Development Authority (MMDA) said on Tuesday. MMDA Chairman Benhur Abalos said the mayors would “rally behind” the President even after the local executives, through its policy board, the Metro Manila Council (MMC), voted 9-8 to have the National Capital Region (NCR) put under a modified GCQ in March. “As what we have always emphasized, the Metro Manila mayors would always defer to the wisdom and judgment of the President,” Abalos said. “We are one with him, and would exert all efforts & rally behind him in combating this Covid-19 (coronavirus disease 2109) pandemic,” he added. The National Economic Development Authority (NEDA) and the Financial Executives Institute of the Philippines, a major business group, recommended the shift to MGCQ to reopen the economy that has been devastated by the pandemic.

headlines: Widen amusement tax coverage, LGUs told
contents: A think tank suggested expanding the coverage of amusement taxes that local government units (LGUs) can impose to include streaming shows as they look for other means to increase their sources of revenues amid the coronavirus pandemic. In a report over the weekend, the National Tax Research Center (NTRC) said local governments need more of these sources to finance their various programs and continue serving their constituents as the Covid-19 crisis persisted. It suggested broadening the scope of the local amusement tax as a way to boost earnings, as “LGUs should not only rely on the fiscal support and allocations from the national government.” Revenue collections from amusement taxes may be insignificant compared to others, but these still contribute to state coffers, the think tank emphasized. Local and national amusement taxes collected reached P887.72 million and P134.50 million, respectively, from 2014 to 2018, according to the report. The cancellation of several entertainment events on account of the pandemic resulted in lower revenues in the Greater Manila Area, where almost half of these came from. The government banned them at the onset of the pandemic, as they encourage mass gatherings that would allow the coronavirus to spread. The estimated revenue loss from taxes collected from SM Prime Holdings Inc. — which operates the Sy Group’s shopping malls, as well as cinemas — alone amounted to P376.39 million at end-September 2020. “As it stands and as construed by the Supreme Court in various cases, Section 140 of the LGC (Local Government Code) of 1991, as amended, is limited only to theaters, cinemas, concert halls, circuses and other places of amusement where one seeks admission to entertain oneself by seeing or viewing the show or performance,” the report said. “In this regard, the coverage of local amusement tax may be broadened to include places that may be considered as places of amusement. In addition, the phrase ‘places of amusement’ must be defined appropriately so as to include other establishments that may be considered as such,” it added. While the pandemic suspended or canceled most shows and programs, there are online streaming shows that can be regarded as sources of amusement, according to the NTRC, noting that people are watching them at home amid the state-imposed mobility restrictions. “The LGUs can tap these sites as sources of tax revenues as the country [adapts to] the new normal,” it said. “LGUs need a broader range of revenue tools. These should include revenue sources that automatically grow with the economy, and at present live streaming may be closely considered as an additional revenue source of LGUs,” the think tank added. “However, it is crucial that social and economic issues are taken into consideration so that new funding sources shift costs fairly on those who can most afford to pay.” The administrative aspect of imposing this tax should also be considered, according to the NTRC. “Congress should consider reviewing the LGC of 1991, as amended, to align the limitations and taxing powers of LGUs to modern business models. For instance, expanding the coverage of local amusement tax may be explored by policymakers to provide additional revenue to LGUs,” it said. “Expanding the local amusement tax coverage will give sufficient leeway for the local sanggunian (council) to explore other activities that may be covered by the local amusement tax,” it added.

headlines: Cebu bishop, priest test positive for Covid-19
contents: Retired Auxiliary Bishop Antonio Rañola tested positive for Covid-19, the Catholic Bishops Conference of the Philippines (CBCP) and the Cebu Archdiocese said in a statement. The 88-year old Rañola, who stays in the same residence with Archbishop Jose Palma of Cebu, was rushed to a hospital in the city on Friday due to severe coughing. The CBCP said Rañola in stable condition. “His vital signs are stable and he is also under close medical supervision by his doctors,” it said in a statement. The CBCP said that Fr. Russel Sungcad was also hospitalized because of Covid-19. He is now in stable condition. Sungcad is currently assigned at the Alliance of Two Hearts Parish in Cebu City’s Banawa district.

headlines: Coronavirus vaccines in the world of make-believe
contents: For weeks now, authorities fighting the pandemic have been simulating the arrival of Covid-19 vaccines and mass inoculations. Of course, it is always better to be prepared. As Benjamin Franklin said, “By failing to prepare, you are preparing to fail.” But with delay after delay in the arrival, the dry runs are becoming less virtuous and more comedic. A Manila health worker shows how to aspire a Covid-19 vaccine from a mock vial, during a mass vaccination simulation activity for senior citizens inside the Legarda Elementary School in Sampaloc, Manila, on 18 February 2021. PHOTO BY MIKE ALQUINTO Indeed, the latest from the Palace is that even President Rodrigo Duterte has grown impatient with the delays. That should have been reassuring, until we remember that he heads the government that is on the receiving end of the blame. Doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech’s Covid-19 vaccine from the Covax Facility were supposed to arrive by mid-February, but delivery was snagged because of vague issues surrounding the indemnity agreement. Also, the 600,000 doses of China’s Sinovac Biotech vaccine expected to arrive on February 23 may also be delayed because the manufacturer has yet to secure emergency use authorization from the local Food and Drug Administration. With frustration growing, the government now has to parry more criticisms than usual. Vice President Maria Leonor “Leni” Robredo, along with other government critics like Sen. Ana Theresia “Risa” Hontiveros, pointed out that even less developed countries like Bangladesh have started inoculations. The observation may be factual but perhaps out of context. Such statements only add to the absurd play and are helpful only in scoring cheap political points. United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres offered a broader perspective on the matter. He said he was alarmed by the global disparity of vaccine distribution. He pointed out that 130 countries have yet to receive vaccines, and that only 10 nations have administered 75 percent of the doses available. Guterres also appealed to the Group of 20 or G20 to bear more of the responsibility for financing and implementing vaccination programs around the world, saying the UN will provide them its full support. “If the virus is allowed to spread like wildfire in the Global South, it will mutate again and again. New variants could become more transmissible, more deadly and, potentially, threaten the effectiveness of current vaccines and diagnostics,” he explained in a story by Agence France-Presse. “This can prolong the pandemic significantly, enabling the virus to come back to plague the Global North.” Those fears are proving to be prophetic. Just on Saturday, The Manila Times reported that two new Covid-19 variants were discovered in Central Visayas. Health experts are still studying these variants, but mutations found elsewhere in the world seem to be more transmissible and virulent, possibly even resistant to the vaccines now being distributed. Consequences of delays Besides more people falling ill or dying, the delays in vaccination will likely spawn black markets and encourage criminal activities. That may already be happening, and if this is true, the situation becomes more complicated for the Duterte government. A few months ago, when media uncovered that the President’s security detail received Covid-19 shots that were smuggled into the country, there were also reports that thousands of Chinese expatriates and Chinese Filipinos had been vaccinated somehow. As we mentioned before in this space, a local black market for vaccines may have already emerged. With people desperate for protection from the pandemic and with the country eager to restart the economy, more may become susceptible to all sorts of schemes. Getting authentic vaccines through unlawful means is one thing, but what if people are duped into paying for fake shots or being injected with placebos? Can buyers tell whether they are getting a flu shot instead of a tested Covid-19 vaccine? Sadly, this issue subsided when President Duterte himself objected to an investigation of the Presidential Security Group (PSG). For the sake of protecting the PSG, there was no directive to look into the vaccine black market. That is yet another act in this unfolding horseplay. The public is distracted by the illusion of movement from simulations, but there is hardly any action. The government needs to get its act together somehow, despite the global issues. More than anything else, that would help bring down the curtains on this tiresome tragedy.

headlines: PH logs 2,240 new cases, highest in Feb
contents:
THE Philippines registered 2,240 new coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) cases on Saturday, its highest in nearly a month, according to the Department of Health (DoH). The highest number of infections registered so far was 2,245 on January 27. Total active cases are at 34,100, of which more than 95 percent are either mild, moderate, or asymptomatic while the rest are severe or critical. There are 513,120 recoveries, including 504 new survivors while 239 more people died, raising the toll to 12,068.

Of the 24,165 samples tested, 1,652 were positive for a positivity rate of 6.8 percent.

Across the globe, coronavirus cases are at 110.7 million, with 2.45 million dead.

headlines: Cebu archbishop tests positive for Covid-19
contents:
CEBU Archbishop Jose Palma has tested positive for the coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19). “He (Palma) tested positive at 10 p.m. (Thursday),” said Msgr. Joseph Tan, the Cebu Archdiocese spokesperson, on Friday. The archbishop, according to Tan, was feeling unwell on Thursday and wanted to be brought to a hospital. “His body felt tired. He was coughing and felt really tired. So, he had a swab test,” he told The Manila Times in Visayan. Palma was brought to Perpetual Succour Hospital where he was confined and is reported to be in stable condition. Tan said Palma did not have any recent travels outside Cebu, and they do not have any idea where the archbishop could have contracted the virus. “Our main concern is to make sure he gets out of the hospital,” the spokesperson added.
Tan said the archbishop’s symptoms included general fatigue and mild cough. “Let us all pray for his steady and speedy recovery,” the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Cebu said in a statement.

headlines: PH logs 1,901 new Covid-19 cases
contents: THE Philippines has logged 1,901 new cases of coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19), raising the count to 557,058, according to the Department of Health (DoH). Of the 32,440 active cases, 95 percent are mild, moderate, and asymptomatic, while the rest remain severe and critical, A total of 512,789 have recovered while the death toll has climbed to 11,829. The positivity rate is at 5.9 percent, with 1,605 out of 27,335 tests by all but four Covid-19 laboratories yielding positive results. There are 110.3 million infections and 2.44 million deaths, according to Johns Hopkins University.

headlines: Manila releases advance payment for AstraZeneca
contents: THE Manila City Government on Friday advanced its payment for 800,000 doses of AstraZeneca vaccine for individuals infected with coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19). Mayor Francisco “Isko Moreno” Domagoso authorized the release of P38.4 million to the British-Swedish company. “Fortunately, the national government allowed LGUs (local government units) to fast-track the procurement process,” Domagoso said. “I am thankful for that.” The Government Procurement Reform Act allows advance payment equivalent to a maximum of 15 percent of the cost of government-financed projects. The amount released by the city is equivalent to 15.36 percent of its P250 million allotment. President Rodrigo Duterte, however, signed a memorandum order increasing the limit for advanced payments for the purchase of the coronavirus vaccines.

headlines: Reopening of cinemas even at 20% capacity pushed
contents: TRADE Secretary Ramon Lopez is urging local governments under the general community quarantine (GCQ) to allow cinemas to operate even at 20 percent capacity to generate more jobs to people affected by the pandemic. During the Laging Handa public briefing on state-run PTV-4 held on Friday, Lopez said that the Department of Trade and Industry’s (DTI) recommendation was based on its observation that those cinemas allowed to open in areas under modified general community quarantine (MGCQ) did not result in higher cases of the coronavirus disease 2019. “Remember, most of the areas in the country are under MGCQ and only about eight places, including the National Capital Region are in GCQ. In areas under MGCQ outside Metro Manila, cinemas are allowed to be open but our observations showed that it did not result in the spike of Covid-19 cases,” he said in Filipino. “Its all about … compliance to health protocols.” Lopez also said that the DTI’s push for cinemas’ reopening is just meant to sustain the gradual reopening of the economy. “We are not violating any laws here. If the LGUs (local government units) are not comfortable, lets start with allowing cinemas to operate at 20 or 30 percent capacity. The only difference is that there will be jobs available for the people,” he added.

headlines: 2 Covid mutations detected in Central Visayas samples
contents: TWO “mutations of clinical concern” of the coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) were found in the samples that were sequenced from Central Visayas, according to the Inter-Agency Task Force on Emerging New Variants. According to Dr. Cynthia Saloma, University of the Philippines-Philippine Genome Center (UP-PGC) director, the E484K and the N501Y mutations were detected in 31 out the 70 samples that came from the region during the sequencing made by the center on February 11. “These are mutations of global concern that were exhibited by variants of concern tulad ng nasa (like in) South Africa, yung sa Brazil and yung sa United Kingdom,” Saloma said in a press conference on Friday. Saloma said the “silent” mutation of the SARS-CoV2 (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome-coronavirus 2) virus was brought about by changes in the sequence of its deoxyribonucleic or ribonucleic acid (DNA/RNA) pairs, and can either cause a loss, gain in function or possibly no change at all. The variants are considered viruses that developed from a specific group of mutations, causing them to behave differently from the strain they originated from. Both mutations can either increase the transmission of Covid-19 and reduce the efficacy of the current vaccines in use, according to Saloma. The cases with these mutations had only exhibited mild symptoms and were cleared. Saloma added that the PGC Genomic Biosurveillance team and the DoH epidemiology bureau will now closely check the genome sequences of the samples and monitor the cases that had been infected with these mutations. Despite the discovery of the new mutations in Central Visayas, Health Secretary Francisco Duque 3rd said that this may not affect Metro Manila’s planned shift to modified general community quarantine (MGCQ) by March 1 as long as the region is careful in enforcing a more relaxed status. “We have to scale up even more in the light of these variants… our massive promotion to let the public comply with all of our minimum public health standards, and the aggressive early detection by way of testing, tracing and isolation,” Duque said.

headlines: Secure and insecure citizenship
contents:
I WAS debating whether to write another article on Covid-19 having first read a very intelligent article in The Atlantic and given the misinformation being peddled by others. There are those who for their personal reasons have an ideological bias that overcomes fact and reason, but I decided against another article that would marginally be bringing up new points given all the major ones that have already been set forth. Maybe if it was substantially on points not previously raised or new verified information rather than rehashing whatever one’s bias dictates and quoting prejudiced sources. On the topic, I am not discussing what is the way we should apply our citizenship laws. While I did work at the Romulo Law Office and passed the bar, my legal career ended in 1984, and I do not pretend to be up to date or remember enough of what I was ably taught decades ago. This is about our attitude toward citizenship and contrast that with others. Many may take issue with my observations, but that is what reasoned discourse is about. I have observed that generally, the more secure a country is, the more liberal their citizenship laws. The less differences in citizenship rights between natural and naturalized, the more open-minded their attitude toward citizenship is. Same is true on how straightforward and open the country is to naturalization. An exception to this is Japan, where like the Philippines one only gets citizenship through jus sanguinis (bloodline — so a parent must be a citizen to bestow citizenship on a child) vs jus soli (where you are born). Places like the US and UK give both jus sanguinis and soli. In Japan you have people who legally work and stay there for generations but because of bloodline never become citizens. That would be the case here as well unless you opt for naturalization. Ironically, it often seems the stricter the citizenship laws, the less desirable the country often is for citizenship anyway. These tend to be the jus sanguinis only countries. Jus soli or jus sanguinis
Why do countries like the US (though the nativist and racist Trump talked about changing it and fortunately his losing ends that immediate fear) apply jus soli? Why do they grant citizenship if you were born there and have for immigrants a relatively straightforward path to citizenship? First, these tend to be countries that had high immigration in their formative years and encouraged it (though the US also has swung the other way under Trump and had its shameful racist periods like the Chinese Exclusion Act and the Japanese incarceration in times of backlash and xenophobia). Second, they tend to be successful and secure countries that argue if you stay here it is because you want to and believe it, to use the popular phrase, to be “the land of opportunity.” Let us not digress into talk among elites who argue about their privileges and so on here vs there. I am talking about opportunity in spite of challenges overall. Those countries are generally not worried that you are going there to exploit the country. You are going there to be part of it. You have bought into their narrative or at least believe that for all the challenges, the opportunities there are better than back home. My one digression that really gets me angry is when people tout the Philippines as paradise because you can have maids and personal help en masse. Guess what? Maybe it is paradise for those who have maids. It is far from paradise for the ones rendering the service. To many and I agree, it is a sign of advancement and civilization that there are enough opportunities in a country that many do not have to be domestic help and if they do so, are compensated enough so it is at least partially a choice rather than something one does for lack of choice or to survive. A paradise is one that is paradise for all or most. Not some tiny sliver only. When my family and I lived in the US, we had no live-in or full-time help. If you needed or wanted someone to come in to clean the house or mow the lawn you contracted with a service, and they would come over, often as a team and do what they needed to in a few hours and then would come back depending on your schedule weekly or as one needed or scheduled. In New York City, it is often an individual rather than a team given most have apartments. Also, the society is structured so you do not need live-in or permanent help to have a comfortable life. The only exception is if you have very young children; then the need to arrange reliable baby-sitters is a chore and can be a challenge. Hence one often sees parents bringing their infants with them to restaurants, cinemas and the like. Related to this is the comment I often hear which is, why do Filipinos do well when abroad? I think it is in large part that our country, 75 years after independence, has not delivered for its ever-increasing population. In our region, Malaysia and Thailand have and Vietnam is clearly on its way to doing so. I remember being so proud after 1986 and so sad for China after 1989. Let us be blunt, absent surface political rights (and I say surface and superficial because who really benefits and can make use of our democratic rights), who is better off if we take conditions prevailing in 1990 as the starting point? On both an individual and country level — the Philippines or China? The answer except for political dissidents is so sadly and blatantly obvious. To go back to the question, why do Filipinos do well abroad while the country underperforms? I used to say, the biggest vote in the Philippines is not the vote for this or that candidate. It is the vote to leave, which tens of millions of Filipinos have taken and continue to take. In my view, Filipinos do well abroad for two reasons — simply because they are incentivized to do so and generally those who go abroad are the more aggressive and adventurous ones. Let us assume you are in a middle position, not happy but not unhappy. Which type of person chooses to stay and which chooses to try something different elsewhere? Who is willing to be away from their families, friends, comfort zone and environment? The latter might not be smarter or wiser and it may be the wrong decision, but that person is definitely more adventurous and open to new ideas and challenges. Guess what? That is what they say in other countries as well, where there is a diaspora until the home country becomes successful and many return home. Natural-born vs naturalized
An offshoot of this is the different rights of natural-born and naturalized citizens. In the US, I think the only differentiator I know is that only a natural-born citizen can be president and if there was fraud in the naturalization process, citizenship can be rescinded. A natural-born citizen cannot have this citizenship removed or revoked. The US requires certain industries like media and transportation and their CEOs to be American. They do not distinguish between natural and naturalized. When he bought the New York Post decades ago, Rupert Murdoch acquired American citizenship to enable himself to be a publisher. Same thing with elected and appointed government officials below president. There was even some fringe speculation during Watergate after VP Agnew resigned that Nixon appointed Kissinger who was a naturalized citizen as vice president as he could not run for and be elected president but if Nixon resigned, he could become president. Don’t know if that view was accurate and many who detest Kissinger would have been aghast if it had happened, but it did not come to pass. Yet some writers speculated on it. Dual citizens
This is another thing secure countries are relaxed about. Mark Carney was the governor of the Central Bank of Canada from 2008 to 2013. Having done an exemplary job and being a dual citizen of Canada and the United Kingdom, he was then made governor of the Bank of England from 2013 to 2020. Economist Stanley Fischer, who was born in what is now Zambia (the former Northern Rhodesia) has dual citizenship — Israeli and American. He was chief economist of the World Bank, then from 2005 to 2013 was governor of the Bank of Israel. In 2014, President Obama appointed him vice chairman of the Federal Reserve. He stepped down for personal reasons in 2017. Jennifer Granholm is both a Canadian and naturalized American citizen and was born in Canada. She was elected and served as governor of Michigan from 2003 to 2011 and has now been appointed secretary of energy by President Biden. What is my point behind these examples? The US, the UK, Canada and Israel did not care if they were dual citizens or naturalized. They just wanted the best and most qualified citizens. Why exclude citizens based on having more than one citizenship or being naturalized? I would suggest in a country like ours, where so many left for opportunity and necessity, why discriminate against them if they want to engage in public service when they return? Recovery of citizenship was a good step but why be so insecure and stop there? The same for naturalized citizens. You must really want to be part of the country if you take an actual step of taking citizenship. If one argues but they left or they got naturalized for opportunistic reasons, my answer is so what? If they are lousy or disloyal, then remove them or vote them out. Are we that insecure? Or jealous?

headlines: UN chief urges global plan to reverse unfair vaccine process
contents: UNITED NATIONS: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres sharply criticized the “wildly uneven and unfair” distribution of coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) vaccines on Wednesday, saying 10 countries have administered 75 percent of all vaccinations and demanding a global effort to get all people in every nation vaccinated as soon as possible. The UN chief told a high-level meeting of the UN Security Council that 130 countries have not received a single dose of vaccine and declared that “at this critical moment, vaccine equity is the biggest moral test before the global community.” Guterres called for an urgent Global Vaccination Plan to bring together those with the power to ensure fair vaccine distribution — scientists, vaccine producers and those who can fund the effort. The secretary-general called on the world’s major economic powers in the Group of 20 to establish an emergency task force to establish a plan and coordinate its implementation and financing. He said the task force should have the capacity “to mobilize the pharmaceutical companies and key industry and logistics actors.” Guterres said Friday’s meeting of the Group of Seven major industrialized nations “can create the momentum to mobilize the necessary financial resources.” British Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab, whose country holds the Security Council presidency this month, urged the UN’s most powerful body to adopt a resolution calling for ceasefires in conflict zones to allow the delivery of Covid-19 vaccines. Thirteen ministers were scheduled to address the meeting on improving access to Covid-19 including US Secretary of State Antony Blinken. Britain says more than 160 million people are at risk of being excluded from coronavirus vaccinations because they live in countries engulfed in conflict and instability, including Yemen, Syria, South Sudan, Somalia and Ethiopia. “Global vaccination coverage is essential to beating coronavirus,” Raab said ahead of the meeting. “That is why the UK is calling for a vaccination cease-fire to allow Covid-19 vaccines to reach people living in conflict zones and for a greater global team effort to deliver equitable access.” Britain’s UN ambassador, Barbara Woodward said: “Humanitarian organizations and UN agencies need the full backing of the council to be able to carry out the job we are asking them to do.” Woodward said cease-fires have been used to carry out vaccinations, pointing to a two-day pause in fighting in Afghanistan in 2001 that enabled 35,000 health workers and volunteers to vaccinate 5.7 million children under the age of 5 against polio. Britain has drafted a Security Council resolution that Woodward said the UK hopes will be adopted in the coming weeks. Mexican Foreign Minister Marcelo Ebrard said Tuesday that Mexico will stress the importance of equal access for all countries to Covid-19 vaccines at the council meeting. He was sharply critical that countries that produce the vaccine have high vaccination rates while Latin American countries have problems obtaining any vaccines. The coronavirus has infected more than 109 million people and killed at least 2.4 million of them. But many countries have not yet started vaccination programs and even rich nations are facing shortages of vaccine doses as manufacturers struggle to ramp up production. The World Health Organization’s COVAX program, an ambitious project to buy and deliver coronavirus vaccines for the world’s poorest people, has already missed its own goal of beginning coronavirus vaccinations in poor countries at the same time that shots were rolled out in rich countries. Numerous developing countries have rushed in recent weeks to sign their own private deals to buy vaccines, unwilling to wait for COVAX. Woodward said Britain supports reserving 5% of COVAX doses as a “last resort” buffer to ensure that high-risk populations have access to Covid-19 vaccines.

headlines: Are supervisors still relevant in the next normal?
contents:
Almost a year ago, Josh Dzieza, investigations editor and feature writer at “The Verge,” wrote an article that could scare today’s Supervisors. The handwriting on the wall looks clear, “In warehouses, call centers and other sectors, intelligent machines are managing humans, and they’re making work more stressful, grueling, and dangerous.” Robo-bosses
Dzieza continues, “The robots are watching over hotel housekeepers, telling them which room to clean and tracking how quickly they do it. They’re managing software developers, monitoring their clicks and scrolls and docking their pay if they work too slowly. They’re listening to call center workers, telling them what to say, how to say it, and keeping them constantly, maximally busy. While we’ve been watching the horizon for the self-driving trucks, perpetually five years away, the robots arrived in the form of the supervisor, the foreman, the middle manager.” Robotics and AI (artificial intelligence) have arrived, and workers in many countries are worried. Dzieza said, “For many of them, their greatest fear isn’t that robots might come for their jobs: it’s that robots have already become their boss.” While many employees detest the thought of being supervised by a robot, a recent survey by Kevin Kruse, CEO of LEADx, revealed that more than 20 percent of workers would want to replace their boss with a generic robot. The LEADx survey results could be unsettling for some supervisors, considering that supervisors have come a long way since the medieval times and have been permanent fixtures in today’s workplace. Origin of supervisor
According to Wikipedia, the word “supervisor” came from the Medieval Latin verb “supervidēre,” meaning “to oversee.” The prefix super (also supra) means “over” or “above”, while the Latin vidēre means “to see.” Literally, to supervise means to see from above. The supervisor is also known by several names — foreman, boss, overseer, monitor, area coordinator or sometimes “gaffer.” In the factory, the supervisor is in a low-level management position. In the academe, the supervisor could be one of the most senior in the staff, such as a Professor who oversees a PhD dissertation. Sometimes, people in the same job grade as the Supervisor are also classified as supervisors, even if they do not supervise other people. Supervisors’ dilemma
Perhaps, supervisors are one of the most misunderstood and stressed people in the workplace. They have productivity-conscious bosses above them and sometimes uncooperative subordinates below them. They’re like the “bibingka,” the Filipino rice cake cooked with fire under it and burning coal on top of it. The first time I was promoted to be a supervisor came as a surprise. I had no training to be one. It seemed that my boss perceived how good I was at doing my clerical tasks. As a reward, I was promoted! Then my headaches began. Here’s why: Like I said, I never had any supervisory skills training before I got promoted. It felt like I was thrown into the pool, and I heard my boss shouting, “Swim!” I was good at technical work, but I never did management or supervisory work. The scope of my job was unclear at first. My friends and fellow employees suddenly became my subordinates. I was not sure if they were ready to accept me as their boss. My sense sometimes told me that some, not all, resented my promotion since many of them had more seniority and longevity in the company. Suddenly, I had two jobs — doing my own and minding the jobs of others. Somehow, I thought that I was programmed to be a rank and file. I had to reprogram my thinking and thought process to be like a manager. It was tough without support from my Manager. To those supervisors who now experience the same dilemma I encountered early in my career, here are some suggestions you might find useful: – Role clarification. First understand your new role — including what you’re supposed to do and what you’re not supposed to do. Ask your boss about his/her expectations and the limits of your authority. Once you’re clear on the parameters with your boss, clarify the same with your subordinates. Whenever possible, take time to discuss this with your subordinates as a group and on a one-on-one basis. Listen to their reactions — verbal and nonverbal — and to what is not being said. – Remain professional at all times. As a new “boss,” you need to establish professional working relationships with your bosses, peers and subordinates. Focus on issues and the tasks at hand, rather than on personalities. Do not shoot the messenger who brings you unsavory news. Be seen as a leader and enabler of others – not bossy, not pushing too hard. – Refrain from office politics. At all cost, avoid corridor or water-cooler politics. Do not side with one party to a dispute that you must arbitrate. Remain neutral, objective and fair always. Don’t get tempted to listen to juicy gossip, lest one day you’re subject of it, too. – Raise your managerial skills. Always sharpen your saw, as Covey said. While the management principles hardly change, the practice is influenced by a number of change drivers in business and in life. Continue to be a student of the art and science of management. Learn the science and adapt it to your working environment. C-3PO as boss?
First-time supervisors must not be wary about lack of supervisory, managerial or leadership skills. They are easily learned from the right sources. What is more worrisome is the development in technology that enables the machines to take over the supervisors’ jobs. The other aspect to worry about is the reaction of workers to the idea of changing a human supervisor with a robot. The younger employees are more willing and ready to trade their current boss with C-3PO. Many employees join a company. But Gallup says employees resign from their bosses. The Gallup survey speaks volumes. Bad bosses are perhaps the major reason for low employee engagement. The LEADx survey says that roughly 30 percent of employees would replace their boss with a friendly humanoid robot-like C-3PO. Recent employee engagement surveys confirm that 30 percent of employees worldwide are disengaged. Coincidence? The LEADx survey revealed the main reasons why employees would replace their bosses with robots: a) they don’t like their boss; 2) their boss is biased; 3) their boss lacks competence; and 4) their boss lacks people skills and empathy. The onus is on supervisors to prove that they are still relevant in the workplace now and in the future. Obviously, humans have characteristics that robots still don’t have, as we write. If the developers and programmers can find a way to program empathy, compassion and love into the DNA of the robots, the supervisors would be among the endangered species. The surveys tend to send a strong warning. People, especially the young, are willing to work with technology, especially in humanoid form, perhaps like Daryl (Data Analyzing Robot Youth Lifeform) in the 1985 movie. People will prefer to have a robot boss if it means getting rid of their bad supervisor. To good supervisors, I say that there’s still a niche for you. As Brian Tracy said, “Only about two percent of people can work entirely without supervision. We call them Leaders.” To the employees, I reiterate my long-time admonition, “Take care of your boss now, the next could be worse — or not human.” Ernie Cecilia is the chairman of the Human Capital Committee of the American Chamber of Commerce of the Philippines (AMCHAM); Co-Chairman of the Employers Confederation of the Philippines’ (ECOP’s) TWG on Labor Policy and Social Issues; and past president of the People Management Association of the Philippines (PMAP). He can be reached at erniececilia@gmail.com

headlines: This pandemic: A punctuated equilibrium
contents: We won’t lose hope. When the sun goes down, the stars will come out. – Anon THE pandemic has punctuated our equilibrium. Applied to various life areas such as in the disciplines — in physics, psychology, economics, management, etc., the term “equilibrium” means balance. Physics-wise, if the resultant of forces on opposite sides of the lever is zero, then there is equilibrium. This pandemic: A punctuated equilibrium. We are witnessing a punctuated equilibrium that has slammed aspects of life. Supply and demand such as for food and health out balance each other; unstable prices of such goods results. Psychology-wise, our mental schemata do not fit the actual environment we are in, be this in our cultural, physical or social environment. Our expectations based on the normal life we knew are incredibly incompatible with the new normal life the pandemic brought about. We need cognitive equilibrium to provide us an intellectual and emotional balance. The social distancing protocols and economic concerns caused by Covid-19 have imposed on us feelings of personal isolation and uncertainty. Obviously, to keep our sanity, we do need equilibrium. Punctuated equilibrium. As we try to calm our nerves in adjusting to this new normal, what can we do to redirect this seismic change? Let us draw understanding of this pandemic from the origin of what paleontologists identified as punctuated equilibrium (PE). The data base explains that there were five PE’s in the last 500 million years. It was a huge meteor or volcanic fury or both, as earth history explains, that caused the ecosystem to change drastically causing the dinosaurs to die. There were a few cold-blooded reptile survivors including crocodiles, but the new ecosystem favored the warm-blooded mammals. Why, because they were able to adapt to the severe weather changes. The PE theory “brings about change,” “after long periods of stability in the characteristics of an organism.” Then comes “short periods of rapid change during which new forms appear.” <dictionary. cambridge.org › dictionary › english › punct…> Similarly, in this pandemic, we are experiencing drastic change. “So, what should be our response to this equilibrium that has been punctuated in our ecosystem? Are we like dinosaurs, or mammals?” Why did the mammals thrive, besides luck? The answer is “Adaptability, adaptability and adaptability.” <www.thoughtworks. com › insights › blog › surviving-o..>. Adapting, would mean a change — a change in us? The equilibrium we need. It is not only a change on market forces that we would seek in the next stage of this pandemic. After a few months of relative calm, “we’ve started to see some striking evolution” of the virus. Biologist Trevor Bedford of the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle wrote of the new strains on Twitter last week. <www.manila times.net › 2021/01/ 20 › news › national>. Unlettered about viruses, most of us did not expect the rise of Covid-19 mutations. They imply an uncertain end of the pandemic, threatening everyone’s psychological health. Gripped with constant fear of contracting the virus or its mutations, we worry over total loss of livelihood, disruption of quality education, a prolonged restriction of social contact, and a host of other uncertainties. Anxiety and/or depression impacts on us both as individuals and on our communities. To lift our spirits, let us count on the positives — the communal spirit of the Filipino which has openly asserted itself many times over. The nimble way is another welcomed change, unlike in prepandemic days, of more government departments in attending to healthcare, education and work interventions to battle with stress and sickness. While physical distance protocol narrows our social life, let’s be thankful for more time we gain for family, creating meaningful relations that we may have failed to nurture due to our professional activities. And thanks for increased awareness to reduce air pollution and greenhouse gases emissions. All these positive developments, we hope would be sustained as we, with much uncertainty, try to adapt to the new normal. Redirecting punctuated equilibrium. Unlike the dinosaurs during the biological PT, we are not experiencing evolving physically. Thankfully, we had temporary stability during massive lockdowns, making us quite used to quarantines; some businesses and tourist spots were allowed to open. However, this short-lived seemingly stable phase, being disturbed by the new pandemic strains coming down on hapless victims, is robbing us of hope that some good change is near at hand. The change we hope for, amidst this massive global-wide uncertainty, is a stable state if there will be. Sadly, the PT theory considered, it proved to be short-lived, punctuated. Thus, to calm our fears, let us stay resilient; hold tight to optimism. Nurture a sense of control. Converse with ourselves. Keep tab of [our] own emotions.” Let’s stay connected with our own family and friends. Bond with the wider community. Extend help where we can. Hold on to hope and faith. This is a challenging phase of the equilibrium. But out of this experience, there comes learning that can “help us build a bridge to the future that is beyond this current crisis.” <www.continuousbreakthruz.com› blog › punctuated-e…> Hold on to our faith and hope in Him. “And when such a future comes, let us be ready and willing to embrace the change.” Putting our heart and mind on this change could be the beginning of a creative tension to initiate a healthy transformation. “There will be no normal to come back to because it is us who will have changed! Our perspectives will have shifted.” In such a punctuated equilibrium, there still is a future to build! Email: ttumapon@liceo.edu.ph

headlines: PH signs ‘no liability’ deal with Pfizer, AstraZeneca
contents: THE Philippine government has signed indemnification agreements with vaccine makers Pfizer and AstraZeneca, vaccine czar Carlito Galvez Jr. said on Wednesday. “Nakapagpirma na po at naisumite na po natin ang mga requirement kasama po dito ang indemnification agreements para sa Pfizer at AstraZeneca, so napirmahan na po namin iyon (We have already signed and submitted all requirements, including the indemnification agreements for Pfizer and AstraZeneca, so we have already signed that),” Galvez said during a Laging Handa public briefing on Wednesday. The indemnification agreements provide that firms will have no liability if ever recipients of vaccines experience adverse effects. Once Pfizer and AstraZeneca sign the deal, the Covax facility can proceed with the delivery of the vaccines to the Philippines. Galvez attributed the delay of the arrival of vaccines from the Covax facility to discussions on the indemnification agreement between the Philippine government and the vaccine manufacturers.

headlines: Palace: ‘New normal’ possible for Covid-free areas
contents: AREAS with no transmission of coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) may be placed under the less stricter “new normal” classification, Malacañang said on Wednesday. In an interview with state-run PTV-4, Palace spokesman Harry Roque Jr. said the Inter-Agency Task Force for the Management of Emerging Infectious Diseases (IATF) was crafting the do’s and don’ts for the possible transition to “new normal” of areas with zero transmission in the past month. “‘Yan naman po talaga ay napagusapan na ng ating IATF at ang inaantay lang po natin ay yung mga do’s and don’ts (That is being discussed by the IATF and we are just waiting for the dos and don’ts),” Roque said when asked of possibly declaring some areas under the “new normal.” Roque, who is also with the IATF, said he would raise again the declaration of the “new normal” in some areas when they meet again. “Hayaan niyo po, sa susunod na IATF [meeting] ay bubuksan ko po muli itong usapin na ito dahil tayo po talaga yung nag move na magdeklara na tayo ng new normal sa mga lugar na wala na pong transmission ng Covid-19 (Don’t worry, in the next IATF meeting, I will once again open this topic because we are the one that moved to declare new normal in areas that no longer have Covid-19 transmission),” he said. “Meron naman po tayong mga lugar na natigil na po ang transmission ng Covid-19 (There are now areas where the Covid-19 transmission already stopped),” he added, without providing other details as to which areas in the country have no coronavirus transmissions. The “new normal” classification used to be the fifth, lowest quarantine classification before the IATF removed it in June. According to IATF’s guidelines on the implementation of community quarantine, “new normal” refers to “emerging behaviors, situations, and minimum public health standards that will be institutionalized in common or routine practices and remain even after the pandemic while the disease is not totally eradicated through means such as widespread immunization.” “These include actions that will become second nature to the general public as well as policies such as bans on large gatherings that will continue to remain in force,” it added. To date, there are only four levels of community quarantine: enhanced community quarantine, which is the strictest; modified enhanced community quarantine, general community quarantine (GCQ), and the modified general community quarantine (MGCQ). For the month of February, areas under GCQ are Metro Manila, Cordillera Administrative Region, Batangas, Tacloban City, Iligan City, Davao del Norte, Davao City, and Lanao del Sur. The rest of the country is currently under MGCQ, the most lenient quarantine classification and the phase before the “new normal.” Current community quarantine classifications are set to lapse after February 28. As of Monday, the country has over 550,000 cases of the coronavirus. Over 510,000 have recovered, while more than 11,000 have died from the disease.

headlines: EU to launch program for ‘second generation’ Covid-19 vaccines
contents: BRUSSELS: The EU will launch a program to study Covid-19 variants and produce “second generation” vaccines against future strains, the bloc’s president has said. The “HERA incubator” program, which begins Wednesday, will bring together the pharmaceutical industry, laboratories, health authorities and researchers, Ursula von der Leyen told French daily Les Echos on Tuesday. “The virus has evolved and will continue to evolve,” said a spokesperson for the bloc —  which has been criticized for its a slow rollout of vaccines so far. “It is important we prepare for mutations.” Member states will also be asked to contribute additional funds so the EU can adapt and modify contracts already signed with vaccine providers and secure doses against future variants, Bloomberg reported. The EU Commission did not comment when contacted by Agence France-Presse. With delays to deliveries of three already-authorized vaccines by AstraZeneca, Pfizer/BioNTech and Moderna, the EU’s medicines regulator is under pressure from European capitals to speed more into service. US pharmaceutical giant Johnson & Johnson is the latest to apply for authorization for its coronavirus vaccine in the EU with a decision possible by the middle of March, Europe’s drugs regulator said Tuesday.

headlines: Duterte signs law to cushion impact of pandemic on financial institutions
contents: PRESIDENT Rodrigo Duterte has signed into law the Financial Institutions Strategic Transfer (FIST) Act which aims to cushion the impact of the coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) pandemic on financial institutions. Presidential spokesman Harry Roque Jr. confirmed this on Wednesday. “Napirmahan na po bilang isang batas ng Presidente ang RA (Republic Act) 11523 o mas kilala bilang Financial Institution Strategic Transfer or FIST Act (The President signed into law RA (Republic Act) 11523 also known as the Financial Institutions Strategic Transfer or FIST Act).” Malacañang thanked Congress for passing the bill, which Roque said was needed amid the crisis brought about by the pandemic. “Napapanahon na po ang pagpasa ng FIST law lalo na sa ngayon na tayo po ay nasa panahon ng pandemya (The passage of FIST law is timely, especially now that we are facing a pandemic).” Senate Bill 1849 and House Bill 6816 which provide mechanisms to allow banks and financial institutions to dispose and transfer non-performing assets and loans had been certified as urgent by the President.

headlines: Covid-19 shots might be tweaked if variants get worse
contents: The makers of Covid-19 vaccines are figuring out how to tweak their recipes against worrisome virus mutations — and regulators are looking to flu as a blueprint if and when the shots need an update. “It’s not really something you can sort of flip a switch, do overnight,” cautioned Richard Webby, who directs a World Health Organization flu center from St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital. Viruses mutate constantly and it takes just the right combination of particular mutations to escape vaccination. But studies are raising concern that first-generation Covid-19 vaccines don’t work as well against a mutant that first emerged in South Africa as they do against other versions circulating around the world. The good news: Many of the new Covid-19 vaccines are made with new, flexible technology that’s easy to upgrade. What’s harder: Deciding if the virus has mutated enough that it’s time to modify vaccines — and what changes to make. “When do you pull the trigger?” asked Norman Baylor, a former Food and Drug Administration vaccine chief. “This is a moving target right now.” The WHO and FDA are looking to the global flu vaccine system in deciding how to handle similar decisions about Covid-19 shots. Influenza mutates much faster than the coronavirus, and flu shots have to be adjusted just about every year. National centers around the globe collect circulating flu viruses and track how they’re evolving. They send samples to WHO-designated labs for more sophisticated “antigenic” testing to determine vaccine strength. The WHO and regulators then agree on the year’s vaccine recipe and manufacturers get to work. For Covid-19 vaccines, Webby said a critical step is establishing a similar surveillance and testing network to flag the mutations that matter. Today, there’s wide geographic variability in tracking and testing mutated versions. For example, Britain does more testing of the changing viral genome than the United States. Three variants first discovered in Britain, South Africa and Brazil are worrisome because of combinations of mutations that make them more contagious. On Sunday, US researchers reported a still different mutation found in seven variants that have cropped up in several states. No one yet knows if this mutation makes the virus easier to spread but the report, not yet vetted by other scientists, urges further research to find out. In this Jan. 22, 2021 file photo, empty vials of the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine are seen at a vaccination center at the University of Nevada in Las Vegas. AP PHOTO Just because a variant is more contagious doesn’t mean it also will be impervious to vaccination. But the variant first identified in South Africa is raising concerns. Columbia University’s David Ho put blood samples from people given the Pfizer or Moderna vaccines into lab dishes with the mutated virus. Vaccine-produced antibodies still protected, but they were much less potent. Preliminary test results of two other vaccine candidates — from Novavax and Johnson & Johnson — soon backed up those findings. Both still protected but were weaker when tested in South Africa, where that variant dominates, than when tested elsewhere. A far smaller test of the AstraZeneca vaccine in South Africa has raised questions about its effect. “If the virus were able to make an additional mutation or two, it could escape even more,” Ho warned. If fully immunized people start getting hospitalized with mutated virus, “that’s when the line gets crossed,” said Dr. Paul Offit, a Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia vaccine expert who advises the FDA. That hasn’t happened yet, but “we should get ready,” he added. Moderna is about to explore one option: Could a third dose of the original vaccine boost immunity enough to fend off some variants even if it’s not an exact match? Columbia’s Ho said it’s a good idea to test because people may “still have plenty of cushion” if their overall antibody levels are very high. In this Jan. 22, 2021 file photo, Tina Killebrew, a certified medical assistant, prepares a dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine at a vaccination center at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas. AP PHOTO Major manufacturers also are developing experimental variant vaccines, just in case. Covid-19 vaccines produce antibodies that recognize the spike protein that coats the coronavirus.
